title: Milecastles
name: Milecastles
description:
It is thought that there were originally eighty-one milecastles along the Wall, traditionally (since the time of R. G. Collingwood) numbered from 0 in the east to 80 in the west. These were situated about one Roman mile (1000 passus = 5000 Rft or 1.48km) apart (it is important to note that Roman miles varied in length across the Roman world and, possibly, between surveyors!). Not all milecastles are known with certainty.
Each milecastle provided a gateway through the Wall and some form of accommodation for a few troops, possibly outposted from adjacent forts.
There are two principle types, long axis (north-south) and short axis (east-west), with four types of gateway (I, II, III, and IV).
